item.title: Associative
item.description:
Let \(A\) be a set. We call a binary operation \(\ast: A \times A \rightarrow A\) associative if for every \(a,b,c \in A\):

\[ (a \ast b) \ast c = a \ast (b \ast c) \]

item.title: Group
item.description:
A group is a non-empty set \(G\) together with a binary operation \(\ast: G \times G \rightarrow G\) such that the following hold:

(Closure) For every \(a,b \in G\), the product \(a \ast b \in G\).

(Associativity) The binary operation \(\ast: G \times G \rightarrow G\) is associative.

(Identity) \(G\) has an identity element.

(Inverse) There exists an inverse element.

We remark that the axiom of closure in this definition is redundant by the definition of a binary operation, which guarantees that \(\ast(G) \subseteq G\).
